Due to consecutive powerful cyclones hitting Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky and its surroundings, the region is experiencing one of the most severe winters in history. For the first time since 1997, such intense blizzards have struck the Russian island in succession.  Because of these back-to-back snowstorms, snow accumulation has reached up to the 3rd and 4th floors. However, claims that snow reached as high as the 10th floor are not true.  This is not about the amount of snow that fell, but rather a situation caused by snow being displaced and piled up on top of each other.  Snow drifts, especially wind-blown drifts and avalanches sliding down from roofs, cause snow to pile up heavily in certain spots, creating the appearance of building-height accumulations in some places.  The lower floors experience intense accumulation (ground snow + drifts), while the upper floors give the impression of â€œsnow at great heightsâ€ due to wind-blown snow plus large masses sliding down from the roofs.
